content.webTitle: Firm accused of hiking rent of ex-crown estate home by 7% in a year

fields.headline: Firm accused of hiking rent of ex-crown estate home by 7% in a year
fields.bodyText: A crown estate tenant of more than 20 years has told how his family’s property was sold off to a private company that has since hiked the rent well above inflation. Jason Wright, from Swaton in Lincolnshire, said he initially faced eviction from his house in 2014 but was given a reprieve when the crown estate confirmed he had an “assured tenancy”, which meant he could stay on despite its sale. Wright, a pastor, said he was given the opportunity to buy the property but could not afford it and it was eventually sold to Dorrington Residential Ltd for about £250,000. The company, which made a £9m pre-tax profit in its most recent accounts, raised the rent by about 7% last year and 3% the year before that, according to Wright. In the last two years inflation has not risen above 2.8%, and in March 2019 it was recorded as 1.8%. Dorrington Residential purchased 50 rural residential properties from the crown estate in September 2015. “Since then, Dorrington have begun to hike the rent up. We had a rent increase last year of about 7%, which is above inflation, which I argued about,” said Wright. “I guess this is going on across the country in properties which have been sold off to big conglomerates like Dorrington.” Wright, who pays £555 a month in rent with his wife, said he is concerned he will never see back the estimated £30,000 he has spent on renovations to the property, which he described as being “derelict” when they moved in. The 48-year-old, who campaigned against the crown estate evictions by setting up a petition, said: “They [the crown estate ] refused to reimburse me any of the money I’d spent on the property although we were promised if it ever swapped hands there would be negotiations on reimbursement or if I ever left the house. So they washed their hands of what they owed me. “When we moved in the house was derelict. I say derelict – I had to replaster the walls. There was no kitchen, there was just a sink. We did a lot of the property on the basis the rent would remain low and we’d be able to stay there until we die.” Wright said he has since been told by Dorrington that he needs to take up the issue with the crown estate, which, he said, was “not interested and basically said if you want to take it further, get a solicitor, but I’m in no position to do that”. After initially being helpful after buying the house, Wright said Dorrington had failed to adequately deal with a number of issues. “They’ve been evasive, very difficult to get anyone to do anything.” He said problems with the front door meant he was not able to lock it properly for a month. “We were unable to lock the door for four weeks so that meant that one door was, well, open. Only today [in May] has the glazier come out and said it needs a new door.” A Dorrington spokesman said: “Under the terms of an assured tenancy the landlord is entitled to carry out an annual review and charge rent at a market level for the property in its current condition. “If the tenant does not accept the proposed new rent then they have the opportunity to refer the matter to the first-tier tribunal, which is part of HM Courts and Tribunals Service. The tribunal will rule on the fairness or otherwise of the proposed rent.” He added: “We aim to respond to a repair request expeditiously and wherever possible to complete the necessary works within 14 days … We have no outstanding repairs at any of our former crown estate properties.” A crown estate spokeswoman said: “In most cases where we are aware that tenants have chosen to undertake substantial improvements to a property, we have agreed from the outset an understanding of how these would be treated at the end of a tenancy.”
